title: Privacy Risks: Not Always Obvious

panelist: Chris Clifton, Computer Science Department, Purdue University

segmentation: How many of you you know feel that you're you know I have experienced the privacy violation of identity theft.
How many people out there been victims of identity theft?
I see a few hands.
I will tell you for privacy.
I can maybe tell how much hair you have and that's about it, OK?
How many of those has your?
Has your data sharing behavior changed because of that identity theft?
A few people.
How many of you are worried about being a victim but haven't been a victim of identity theft?
Oh, lots of hands now.
And how many of you?
How does this affected your data sharing behavior?
Lot of hands.
Are you unhappy with how your data is used sometimes?
Yeah, and a lot of hands.
Does this change what you do?
Yes.
So what does this mean to data science for social good?
Now this is just a very simple example of a few privacy violations and you notice.
It's not even the people who were actually victims of an occurrence.
People are changing their behavior just because of the fear that they may have a privacy vial.
So what does this mean for us?
Societal impact here we are trying to mine this data for social good.
So what do you do to protect yourself?
Well.
One thing you can do, and let's see if this clicker is going to advance for me.
Is you withhold data?
How many have done that have not provided data that's been asked for?
OK, so could we mine null for social good?
Not very well.
What's more?
There's a there's a harm here, lack of discourse if we're afraid to talk.
If we're afraid to share information.
What happens for those of us in the US to our First Amendment?
Maybe the government's not coming after us, but the fear that maybe they are listening in is enough to stop that discourse and be just as bad as if something was happening.
Well, what else can we do?
How many people have provided false data?
Lot of people have done that.
Can we mine garbage for social good?
Well, apparently in New York they can.
For those of you who heard the talk last night.
But for most of us.
You know?
We can't mine garbage for social good.
We need good data.
And what's more, the individuals, by providing false data, you lose the benefit.
That can come from giving good information you get.
Wrong recommendations.
You get things that aren't useful.
And the nuclear option.
Shut down the dataminers.
For those of you who recognize the picture of the tombs.
This is not a joke.
How many of you remember Senate enrolled Bill 188 the data Mining Moratorium Act of 2003?
Six years later, Senate Amendment 3131, a prohibition on data mining.
Now admittedly, these were not wide scope.
These weren't completely eliminate everything, but 3131 was a restriction on use of healthcare data for data mining.
And let's see 2003 + 6 is 2009 + 6 is well, let's see what happens in the next Congress.
So my claim is if we don't worry about protecting privacy.
We're not going to do data mining for social good because we won't have the data or we won't have the authority to do it.
So privacy is something we need to be concerned about.
Even if we really aren't concerned about privacy.
It's necessary.
